Topic.Title: Earnings estimates

Message.Msg: I was pleasantly surprised by how fast Intel intends to move on 450mm wafer implementation. This will bring another huge process lead in addition to its economic benefits. Intel is building and installing the technology that will allow them to be more profitable at each smaller process node while ARM has failed to make these same investments (well, they couldn't because of the broken fabless, capital-less model). How Wall Street can miss so many huge strategic moves is a total mystery...

You don't think that's enough to position it for a significant move up? Look at the P/E ratio for goodness sakes. Message.Title: ARM and Window RT have been torpedoed by the Atom
Message.Msg: Samsung has stopped selling the device in Europe because of zero demand.

Message.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?
Message.Msg: The fact of the matter is that the A15 is a power hog and cannot be used in a smartphone. It seems arm's design has topped out with the A7. Samsung is dropping their A15 Exynos in favor of qcom's snapdragon in their next Galaxy products. The arm market is slowly consolidating to qcom's designs. The only viable competition to qcom's will be Intel's Atom design.

Message.Msg: done well since she became CEO.

Topic.Title: Intel should have hired Marisa Mayer as new CEO. Yahoo stock has

Message.Msg: Since Marisa is taken, Intel should hire Mark Hurd as CEO. He'll mess up the company, but the stock should do extremely well.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: The A15 gives the chip a high performance top end while the A7 gives it a low power bottom. Under typical usage condition where most of the time you're web browsing and checking email and only sometimes playing games, this gives a power/performance profile well matched to the usage -- that's the point of big.LITTLE.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: Then why is Samsung droping the big.Little Exynos design in favor of qcom snapdragon for the next Galaxy products? And why is qcom not designing any SoC based on big.Little? The reason is big.Little is a gimmick and is not supported by software developers because it puts the switching logic on the software side. Software developers do not want to add code to determine power usage and which processor to use. Without support from software developers, big.Little will go nowhere.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: Intel looked very, very closely at A 15 - no reason why Intel should not be able to implement the concept of A15 if they felt it would be necessary. There is NOTHING reveloluntionary about A15 A15 = -Tojota Prius ... you use low power when you cruise and get additional horses when accelerating.

Message.Title: Build it and they will come
Message.Msg: Intel is building up their capacity because they know they have tremendous process lead. Companies and climbing over each other to try to get a piece of it. Any company that does not sign with Intel will have major competitive disadvantage. This is the reason why Altera signed with Intel. This is the reason why Cisco will be sign up next, then Motorola, then Apple...

Message.Title: Events that will ignite Intel's stock
Message.Msg: - new CEO to be announced soon. Imagine what the stock will do when a new dynamic CEO is announced..think Marisa Mayer - Haswell introduction. Pent up demand for PC will finally be released as corporations and consumers buy up new thinner and lighter with 10 hours battery life hybrid PCs. Think of a lighter and thinner Lenovo yoga, or Helix or Asus Transformer book. Apple's PC products will also be upgraded with the new chip. All these devices will have 10 hours battery life! - New Bay Trail Atom SoC introduction. These will beat any current and next generation ARM SoC in both performance and battery life. Imagine a hybrid PC that is 8mm thin and have over 12 hours battery life and have integrated LTE 4G. Bay Trail will go into smartphones as well. A new breed of smartphones that run full Windows 8 Pro OS may be born.

Topic.Title: Events that will ignite Intel's stock

Message.Msg: - iWatch introduction with Intel inside. Imagine having a watch that wirelessly connects to your iPhone so that you can read emails and text message without needing to pull your phone out of your pocket or handbag. Imagine how convient it would be to have your iWatch provide you with turn by turn directions as you drive. Imagine working out or going on a jog without the need to carry your phone as you listen to your favorite songs thru your iWatch. The iWatch will be a sure hit!

Topic.Title: Events that will ignite Intel's stock

Message.Msg: - Intel's Web TV and set-top box introduction. Intel's web tv service will be the first to allow you to watch tv anywhere, any place, any time. On top of this, you can record any show thru a cloud-based dvr. You can also access any show you missed or forgot to record. On top of this, you also can rent and stream movies just like Netflix. With the set-top box and it's integrated WiDi (and Miracast), you can watch TV from any WiDi enabled device including your computer, tablet or phone.

Topic.Title: Events that will ignite Intel's stock

Message.Msg: - New foundry deals. Expect for Cisco to sign a major foundry deal with Intel in the near future. This deal could add $2 billion per year in revenue for Intel.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: No. big.Little is more like a 2 speed manual transmission car. It is not smart enough to know when to shift gear so requires the driver (software developer) to do it. It is an outdated concept and is really a baid-aid solution to compensate for the power hog A15.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: No. big.Little is more like a 2 speed manual transmission car. It is not smart enough to know when to shift gear so requires the driver (software developer) to do it. It is an outdated concept and is really a baid-aid solution to compensate for the power hog A15. ---- No. The software developer needs to do nothing. It's all under hardware/OS control.

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: Then why is Samsung droping the big.Little Exynos design in favor of qcom snapdragon for the next Galaxy products? And why is qcom not designing any SoC based on big.Little? The reason is big.Little is a gimmick and is not supported by software developers because it puts the switching logic on the software side. Software developers do not want to add code to determine power usage and which processor to use. No software developer will need to do anything in regards to big/little...

Topic.Title: If ARM's designs are so power efficient, why the need for big.Little?

Message.Msg: The fact of the matter is that the A15 is a power hog and cannot be used in a smartphone. It seems arm's design has topped out with the A7. Samsung is dropping their A15 Exynos in favor of qcom's snapdragon in their next Galaxy products. The arm market is slowly consolidating to qcom's designs. The only viable competition to qcom's will be Intel's Atom design. ----- QCOM is using other ARM cores (such as the A5 and A7) in some of it's app processors and basebands - these chips are still called snapdragon. What you are talking about is Krait, which is QCOM's own design to the ARM ISA, ARM still earns cash on every Krait shipped. As for the A15, yes, it can fit in a smart phone power envelope. Big/little is all about the power/performance curve. Look it up.

Topic.Title: ARM Server maker can port x86 to ARM

Message.Msg: Porting code cannot be done easily and will be not be perfect. This is the reason why ARM will not make a dent in server market, especially now that Intel has low power Atom server chips. It is the same with the PC market - ARM PCs won't make a dent. Corporations have all their software running on x86 --- Depending on the application and the OS, porting takes seconds. The LAMP stack has been running on ARM for years, but now that you've got the major Linux disro's supporting ARM it's a simple recompile in many cases (a step you would have to do on x86).

Topic.Title: ARM, Intel Technicals

Message.Msg: It was actually 5 attempts http://finance.yahoo.com/q/hp?s=ARMH+Historical+Prices I also have a gut feeling 44.47 will prove to be the very top for the foreseeable future. Any ARM fabrication delays are not really a problem from a cost/size POV as their chips are naturally small anyway. The issue is transistor performance and power for their designs, their A15 will need sub 20nm FinFETs to behave like a proper successor to A9 because at the moment it looks like a netbook chip that they are trying to shoehorn into tablets and phones.

Topic.Title: ARM, Intel Technicals

Message.Msg: The issue is transistor performance and power for their designs, their A15 will need sub 20nm FinFETs to behave like a proper successor to A9 because at the moment it looks like a netbook chip that they are trying to shoehorn into tablets and phones ---- The A15 was designed for the 28nm node, while the new 64bit cores where design for 20nm. You will get some cross over. A single A15@1.8Ghz going full pelt on 28nm will draw just over 1.5 watts. Easily getting it with the budget of a phone. Clearly, running multiple threads/cores will blow the power budget, but this is just like existing Atoms of today (with the turbo boost).

Topic.Title: ARM Server maker can port x86 to ARM

Message.Msg: If the LAMP stack has run on ARM for years, then why hasn't ARM already made more progress in the server market? 1). There's no compelling reason to do so, 2). Most server apps require far more than LAMP, 3). Code that doesn't run the CPU's native instruction set doesn't perform as well.

Topic.Title: ARM Server maker can port x86 to ARM

Message.Msg: If the LAMP stack has run on ARM for years, then why hasn't ARM already made more progress in the server market? 1). There's no compelling reason to do so, 2). Most server apps require far more than LAMP, 3). Code that doesn't run the CPU's native instruction set doesn't perform as well. ---- Well, it depends on your definition of a 'server' for a start. As an example, many SOHO NAS boxes are now ARM based and these boxes are mini servers (file, web etc). LAMP is a huge (Linux, Apache, Mysql, Perl/PHP/Python) set of software and if this lot works on a SoC then the battle is halfway won. Our server software for example, is C based and as long as there is a modern Linux distro then it would compile on ARM (as we don't do anything that low down to be ISA specific). I'm not sure what you are talking about regarding 3), but code is code, it'll be compiled to native (C/C++) or run as scripts (in the case of Perl/PHP/Python).

Message.Title: Rumor: Intel to build ARM chips
Message.Msg: Talk about a deal that would kill all the ARM shorts, lol. Apple, Intel in talks for chip deal -- report The companies have reportedly been in discussions for the past year, but so far, haven't come to an agreement. by Don Reisinger | March 7, 2013 7:02 AM PST Apple's A6X processor. (Credit: James Martin/CNET) Intel might be trying to line up Apple's chip production, according to a new report. The companies over the past year have been in talks for Apple to move its mobile chip production from Samsung to Intel, Reuters is reporting today, citing people who have knowledge of their discussions. So far, however, Intel and Apple have been unable to reach an accord. That Apple and Intel have talked boosts a claim made last week to Reuters by Intel custom foundry vice president and general manager Sunit Rikhi that his company is ramping up to take on a major mobile customer. Rikhi declined, however, to say that the customer could be Apple. Reuters' report comes a couple of months after RBC Capital Markets analyst Doug Freedman said that Apple and Intel might be imagining a new partnership in which Intel would build the iPhone maker's ARM-based smartphone chips in exchange for it using Intel's X86 processors in its next-generation iPad. Apple has relied on Samsung for years to build its mobile processors. However, as that company's mobile efforts continue to pressure Apple's, the iPhone maker is looking for alternatives. In addition to Intel, Taiwan Semiconductor, among other chip makers, have reportedly been considered by Apple. CNET has contacted both Intel and Apple for comment on the Reuters report. We will update this story when we have more in

Message.Title: Rumor: Intel to build A-Series chips
Message.Msg: Thursday, March 07, 2013, 05:43 am Rumor: Apple and Intel again mulling partnership to build A-series chips By AppleInsider Staff A report on Thursday claims inside knowledge of reported negotiations between Apple and Intel, saying the chip maker may be looking to build ARM-based SoCs based for the Cupertino company's iOS device lineup. Citing a person familiar with one of the tech giants, Reuters reported that executives have over the past year discussed a possible partnership in which Intel's foundries would be used to manufacture Apple-designed chips. A deal has not yet been reached, the source said. This is not the first time rumors of an Apple-Intel partnership have cropped up. A report from May 2011 suggested that Intel showed interest in building Apple's A4 and A5 SoCs, though no action was taken and the idea was apparently shelved as the so-called Ultrabook initiative gained momentum. Intel is supposedly looking to shift its strategy as PC sales continue to slump as mobile devices, led by tablets like Apple's iPad, continue to gobble up marketshare. The firm has been looking to expand its foundry business, most recently agreeing to fabricate silicon based on technology from chip maker Altera. While an agreement to start production of ARM SoCs would likely undercut adoption of Intel's own Atom mobile processor, the move might be necessary to keep pace with a quickly changing market. The report also speculates that Intel's replacement for CEO Paul Otellini, who plans to retire in May, may further diversify the company's contract operations in a bid to keep manufacturing facilities working at full capacity. As for Apple, a move to Intel is easier to imagine, as the Mac lineup already runs on x86 processors. It has also been rumored that the company wants to distance itself from current A-series SoC manufacturer Samsung, with which it is ensnarled in a worldwide patent struggle.

Message.Title: Intel Inside...Apple Outside
Message.Msg: All the talk of Intel using it's fab advantage to gain Apple's chip business is laughable. When Apple looks inside one of Intel's newest fab factories they only wish they could get "inside". There is no way Intel will manufacture ARM based designed chips. The first criteria that Intel states as a requirement for taking on a fabless client is that they are not a "competitor" and will not be taking market share. If Apple wants to use Intel fab facilities, then it will have be using X86 and like the MacBook use an Intel designed chip. The next obvious step is for Apple to get all of their MacBooks to be "touch" enabled and then to start running all of their iOS compatible devices on the same X86. The main contention is PRICE, pure and simple dollars and cents. Apple is so accustomed to dictating price/cost to every one of their suppliers that they are having a hard time getting Intel to concede the their low ball price structure. The ARM designed chips inside the iPhone and iPad are cheap. Intel demands a higher and more fair price and Apple is unable to bring themselves to pay for these costs. After all, how do you account for the $138 BILLION cash hoard they have amassed over the last few years? Foxcon can only charge what Apple says they will pay. Ever wonder why they have Foxcon employees jumping off the roof of their factories when forced to put in 12 hours shifts and living like sardines inside 12 story dormitories? Apple is all about profit at the expense of others hard work and investment. This is why the fabless model is broken and Apple is no different than any other of those companies that don't put up the amount of R&D and capex expenditures like Intel. Yes, Apple will be putting a $Billion or so into their new "Space Station" campus headquarters. Yet, they will still be on the "outside" looking "inside" Intel.

Topic.Title: Intel Inside...Apple Outside

Message.Msg: Good points, san-warzone. My view exactly. But, I believe that with the recent crash in their stock price, Apple and Tim Cook would be more willing to deal. There has been a lot of pressure from hedge funds for Apple to do something about distributing more dividends, do buybacks, and get the stock price back up - and investors will continue breathing down Tim Cook's neck till he does some strategic moves. With Samsung becoming more of a competitor, and TSMC being fairly shaky in terms of sub 28nm processes, Tim will have no choice but to do a deal with Intel. And if that calls for swapping ARMH core for an x86, he may just have to work towards that transition. Frankly, with Intel having a clear roadmap up to 5nm, it is not at all a bad transition for Apple.

Message.Title: Apple/Intel Deal will happen
Message.Msg: Intel is currently a customer of ARMH and uses some of it's technology in controllers for SDD's. It's not a question of "if" Intel would ever make an ARM processor, they already do. Though Apple may not be out front in new innovation introduction they still seem to have excellent follow through. Windows 8 was the first step of Microsoft to offer one operating system that ran from PC's to smartphones. It was flawed by having it come out on two different platforms. Apple will probably not make the same mistakes. They've made no secret that their OS and iOS platforms will eventually merge. They just need to start taking the steps to make this happen. The smartphone is currently a lighter version of a PC. Eventually it will be a PC. The hardware is heading that direction. In the short term yes there are the issues of doing business with Samsung who is starting to beat Apple at the very market it developed. Long range there is the vision of having smartphone that are actual PC's entrenched deeper in people's everyday life. Perhaps the future innovation for Apple really isn't about the next big idea but instead enhancing prior innovations to fit even more seamlessly into our lifestyle.

Topic.Title: Apple/Intel Deal will happen

Message.Msg: Yes, Steve Jobs would have done this, it was part of his vision. And the iPad Mini wasn't anywhere in his vision. But the company has moved on from his vision and they are too scared to rock the boat. Tim Cook is worrying about sinking stock prices, porting to ARM64 would be his death nail. Intel will make the A processor for Apple, at first. Then they can start collaboration long term about which processors make the most sense. Heck, it may even be a propitiatory processor. Intel/Apple has some interesting joint projects like Thunderbolt. Apple and Intel have thus far played fairly nicely together, better than they have with Samsung.

Topic.Title: Apple/Intel Deal will happen

Message.Msg: And, in your mind, Apple is going to keep pushing its processor design going head-to-head against Intel? ---- I wasn't being that serious. Remember, it's about the SoC's performance not just the CPU so you would expect lots of things to be on die (network, disc controllers) which will keep costs down and up (io) performance. CPU design is changing, lots of interesting stuff about and Apple may go radical for increased system performance.

Topic.Title: Apple/Intel Deal will happen

Message.Msg: The film and music industry is one of Apple's most lucrative markets. Film editors and creative types purchase the fastest, most expensive gear Macbooks and workstations Apple sells because these folks need all the speed they can get. ARM has nothing that can serve this market. Apple will give up this market if they try to standardize on ARM. ---- It would be their own CPU so wouldn't be constrained by a power consumption design point as low as ARM's own CPU's. This workload is the kind of thing that can be done in hardware (via API's like OpenCL) so one solution is to add compute GPU's to the SoC to boost performance well beyond what you can do on today's machines

Topic.Title: Apple/Intel Deal will happen

Message.Msg: Adding GPU's to the design doesn't solve the problem. Videographers that use applications like Adobe Premiere Pro already use multiple discrete graphics cards with thousands of combined CUDA cores but what they learned is that CUDA cores by themselves shorten transcode times by only a modest amount. The most effective way to shorten the video editors job is for one to get the fastest multi-core host CPU they can find plus thousands of CUDA cores. It is simply urealistic to believe Apple will produce an entire range of custom ARM CPU's across the entire computing spectrum that will be competitive to what Intel already has.

Message.Title: Texas Instruments Raises Low End of Sales, Profit Forecasts
Message.Msg: TI warns .... better than expected. Texas Instruments Raises Low End of Sales, Profit Forecasts By Ian King - Mar 7, 2013 3:26 PM PT Texas Instruments Inc. (TXN), the largest maker of analog chips, raised the lower end of its forecasts for first-quarter sales and profit, as customers increase orders ahead of a projected rebound in electronics demand. Earnings will be 28 cents to 32 cents a share on sales of $2.8 billion to $2.91 billion, the Dallas-based company said today in a statement. On Jan. 22, Texas Instruments said profit would be 24 cents to 32 cents on revenue of $2.69 billion to $2.91 billion, and analysts on average had predicted 29 cents and $2.81 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Texas Instruments has thousands of customers across the electronics industry, from radar-equipment suppliers to microwave-oven makers, meaning its earnings are one of the broadest proxies for the health of the chip market. After running down inventories last year, some companies have resumed buying parts to ensure they aren’t caught short when demand returns, said Tore Svanberg, an analyst at Stifel Nicolaus & Co. “Order rates are still improving, from obviously a low level,” said Svanberg, who recommends buying the shares. “The industrial market and especially automotive is showing some strength. We’re still very early in the process.”

Topic.Title: Its a NO BRAINER folks. Apple will go with Intel Atom. They have no choice.

Message.Msg: There is certainly a compelling argument for that conclusion. While Microsoft seems to have a talent for stumbling their way to success at least they have a vision to unify their platforms with a single OS kernel from smartphone to server. With Intel's broad processor lineup they also have the means to execute on that strategy. Already there is a company that offers full Windows 8 on a cellphone that fits into a telephone handset docking station and enables the handset to become the person's PC with full W8 when the person is at their desk. This is an extremely useful glimpse what the future holds for desktop and application portability and together Intel and Microsoft have the inside track. Apple has no path because of the bifurcated processor strategy. Legacy MAC OS apps aren't going to be ported to ARM ISA any more than legacy Windows apps have been ported to ARM. It's the same reason Windows RT is dead or dying. If Apple intends to have a meaningful place in the future they need to have a single instruction set across all their platforms. There is no absolutely no doubt Intel is capable of delivering processors to serve all of Apple's products, but more importantly, there is no evidence at all to believe that ARM can.

Topic.Title: Its a NO BRAINER folks. Apple will go with Intel Atom. They have no choice.

Message.Msg: I couldn't agree more with this argument. It's so dumb that these analysts and media keep pounding table about Apple's foundry business going to Intel (or Intel should be begging for that business) but that idea, at best, is stupid and counter-productive for Intel. Why would any company like Intel would want to manufacture and improve the efficiency of it's competitor's chips by providing their enviable foundry platform? why??? I don't think they want prove that ARM chips can run better by throwing their foundry tech. prowess. It's in the best interest of Apple to switch away from BIG.LITTLE new kid on block on to more proven, more portable, more superior vendor who could match power efficiency of ARM even with their superior/PC processors. Apple should stop thinking about 'I-wanna-be-Intel' idea. It's just not their business. They good at consumer experience. Steve was smart when he switched to Intel from IBM just for those same reasons.

Message.Title: Apple, Intel In Talks Over Chip Manufacturing Deal
Message.Msg: Intel's quest to become a foundry business may include Apple. Don't get your hopes up that an x86-based iPhone is on the way. A possible allegiance between Intel and Apple only means that the chip maker simply wants to manufacture chips for other companies to make up for revenue lost in a declining PC market. Last week Intel said that it will open up its manufacturing plants to fellow chipmaker Altera, the first in Intel's foundry business. That's big news considering Intel has spent decades hoarding its prized manufacturing technology to itself. But given that the PC market is declining and Intel's fabrication plants are operating at less than full capacity, it was only a matter of time before Intel decided to open those plants to other companies. "Altera's FPGAs using Intel 14-nm technology will enable customers to design with the most advanced, highest-performing FPGAs in the industry," said John Daane, president, CEO and chairman of Altera. "In addition, Altera gains a tremendous competitive advantage at the high end in that we are the only major FPGA company with access to this technology." Now there's talk that Apple plans to be the next customer. An unnamed source close to both companies told Reuters that top Intel and Apple executives have discussed a possible relationship over the past year. So far no actual agreement has been made. "If you can have a strategic relationship where you're making chips for one of the largest mobile players, you should definitely consider that. And for Apple, that gets them a big advantage," said Pat Becker Jr., of Becker Capital Management. His firm owned about $39 million worth of Intel shares at the end of last year. Reuters reports that Intel's plan to become a foundry business includes heavy capital spending while it continues to struggle in both the desktop and mobile markets. Intel has yet to find enough new demand to fill future fabrication plans, and it will likely become highly vulnerable to economic swings
